cleaned_text: CALIFORNIA CALIFORNIA LAW REVISION COMMISSION TENTATIVE RECOMMENDATION California Public Records Act Clean-Up May 2019 The purpose of this tentative recommendation is to solicit public comment on the Commission's tentative conclusions. A comment submitted to the Commission will be part of the public record. The Commission will consider the comment at a public meeting when the Commission determines what, if any, recommendation it will make to the Legislature. It is just as important to advise the Commission that you approve the tentative recommendation as it is to advise the Commission that you believe revisions should be made to it. COMMENTS ON THIS TENTATIVE RECOMMENDATION SHOULD BE RECEIVED BY THE COMMISSION NOT LATER THAN August 26, 2019. The Commission will often substantially revise a proposal in response to comment it receives. Thus, this tentative recommendation is not necessarily the recommendation the Commission will submit to the Legislature. California Law Revision Commission c/o UC Davis School of Law Davis, CA 95616 650-494-1335 <commission@clrc.ca.gov> SUMMARY OF TENTATIVE RECOMMENDATION The California Public Records Act ("CPRA") was enacted in 1968 to promote public access to public records, while also recognizing competing interests. In enacting the CPRA, the Legislature, "mindful of the right of individuals to privacy," found and declared that "access to information concerning the conduct of the people's business is a fundamental and necessary right of every person in this state." Since its enactment, the CPRA has been revised over and over again, in piecemeal fashion. This has resulted in a statute that is poorly organized and cumbersome for members of the public to use and understand, impeding fulfillment of the goals underlying the CPRA. To address that problem, the Legislature asked the Law Revision Commission to study the CPRA on a priority basis and prepare a report containing recommended legislation that would make the CPRA more user-friendly, without changing its substance. More specifically, the Legislature asked the Commission to develop legislation that would: (1) Reduce the length and complexity of current sections. (2) Avoid unnecessary cross-references. (3) Neither expand nor contract the scope of existing exemptions to the general rule that records are open to the public pursuant to the current provisions of the CPRA. (4) To the extent compatible with (3), use terms with common definitions. (5) Organize the existing provisions in such a way that similar provisions are located in close proximity to one another. (6) Eliminate duplicative provisions. (7) Clearly express legislative intent without any change in the substantive provisions. The Commission has been studying the CPRA as directed. This tentative recommendation is its current draft of the requested report. In preparing this draft, the Commission has taken great care to ensure that the proposed recodification of the CPRA would not make any substantive change in the law. The Commission seeks comments on this tentative recommendation. Comments from knowledgeable persons (whether positive, negative, or more nuanced) are crucial in the Commission's study process. This tentative recommendation was prepared pursuant to Resolution Chapter 158 of the Statutes of 2018. Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 1 - CALIFORNIA PUBLIC RECORDS ACT CLEAN-UP In 2016, the Legislature directed the Law Revision Commission to conduct a 1 strictly nonsubstantive clean-up of the California Public Records Act ("CPRA")1 2 and related provisions. The Legislature requested that the Commission complete 3 this work "as soon as possible, considering the Commission's preexisting duties 4 and workload demands ...."2 5 This tentative recommendation presents a complete draft of a proposed 6 recodification of the CPRA to make it more user-friendly, without changing its 7 substance. The Commission seeks comments on the proposed recodification. 8 The history and purposes of the CPRA are discussed briefly below, followed by 9 a discussion of the history and purposes of this study. The Commission then 10 describes the general character and noteworthy features of the proposed 11 recodification, as well as the methodology used in preparing it. 12 Unless otherwise indicated, all further statutory references are to the 13 Government Code. 14 History and Purposes of the CPRA 15 The CPRA was enacted in 1968 to promote public access to public records, 16 while also recognizing competing interests.3 In enacting the CPRA, the 17 Legislature, "mindful of the right of individuals to privacy," found and declared 18 that "access to information concerning the conduct of the people's business is a 19 fundamental and necessary right of every person in this state."4 20 "[P]eople in an open society do not demand infallibility from their institutions, 21 but it is difficult for them to accept what they are prohibited from observing."5 The 22 CPRA thus serves "a crucial function."6 As the California Supreme Court has 23 explained: 24 Implicit in the democratic process is the notion that government should be 25 accountable for its actions. In order to verify accountability, individuals must 26 1. Gov't Code §§ 6250-6276.48. 2. 2016 Cal. Stat. res. ch. 150 (ACR 148 (Chau)); see also 2018 Cal. Stat. res. ch. 158 (SCR 91 (Roth)) (reaffirming Commission's authority to study CPRA). 3. See 1968 Cal. Stat. ch. 1473. 4. 1968 Cal. Stat. ch. 1473, § 39 (Section 6250). 5. Richmond Newspapers v. Virginia, 448 U.S. 555, 572 (1980). 6. City of San Jose v. Superior Court, 2 Cal. 5th 608, 615, 389 P.3d 848, 214 Cal. Rptr. 3d 274 (2017). Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 2 - have access to government files. Such access permits checks against the arbitrary 1 exercise of official power and secrecy in the political process.7 2 Although public access to public records is of great importance, it must 3 sometimes yield to a competing interest.8 Thus, the CPRA "contains numerous 4 exemptions to the requirement of public disclosure, many of which are designed to 5 protect individual privacy." 9 Under the CPRA, the public "is entitled to inspect 6 public records unless one of the exemptions ... applies."10 7 The CPRA thus strikes "a careful balance" between the right of public access 8 and competing considerations.11 Since its enactment, the Legislature has 9 continually refined that balance, adjusting the statutory scheme over and over 10 again in an incremental manner as new issues surfaced.12 11 Due to the piecemeal nature of these repeated reforms, the CPRA has developed 12 into a complicated tangle of statutory provisions. In its present form, it is hard for 13 users (especially non-lawyers) to comprehend and follow, and hard for the 14 Legislature to place new material where it logically belongs. 15 Here are a few illustrations: 16 Instead of being grouped together, provisions with the same subject matter 17 are sometimes separated in ways that can make key material hard to find. 18 For example, Section 6254(f) is a long and complicated exemption 19 pertaining to law enforcement records, with multiple caveats, qualifications, 20 exceptions, and exceptions to the exceptions. Sections 6254.30 and 6262 21 7. Id., quoting Internat'l Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers, Local 21, AFL-CIO v. Superior Court, 42 Cal. 4th 319, 328-29, 165 P.3d 488, 64 Cal. Rptr. 3d 693 (2007) (internal quotation marks omitted). 8. City of San Jose, 2 Cal. 5th at 615; see, e.g., Commission on Peace Officer Standards & Training v. Superior Court, 42 Cal. 4th 278, 288, 165 P.3d 462, 64 Cal. Rptr. 3d 661 (2007). 9. Commission on Peace Officer Standards & Training, 42 Cal. 4th at 288. 10. Id. 11. City of San Jose, 2 Cal. 5th at 616; see also Copley Press, Inc. v. Superior Court, 39 Cal. 4th 1272, 1282, 141 P.3d 288, 48 Cal. Rptr. 3d 183 (2006) (Judicial decisions interpreting CPRA "seek to balance the public right to access to information, the government's need, or lack of need, to preserve confidentiality, and the individual's right to privacy."). The statutory balancing of competing interests in the CPRA is similar to the interplay between two sometimes conflicting provisions of the California Constitution: the people's right of access to information concerning the conduct of the people's business (Cal. Const. art. I, § 3) and the right of privacy (Cal. Const. art. I, § 1). See, e.g., City of San Jose, 2 Cal. 5th at 616 ("Similarly, while the Constitution provides for public access, it does not supersede or modify existing privacy rights."); Commission on Peace Officer Standards & Training, 42 Cal. 4th at 288 (comparing balancing in California Constitution with balancing in CPRA). 12. See, e.g., Assembly Committee on Judiciary Analysis of ACR 148 (April 19, 2016), p. 3 ("Since the enactment of the CPRA, it has been amended multiple times to exempt certain records."); Senate Committee on Judiciary Analysis of ACR 148 (June 14, 2016), p. 4 (referring to "nearly 50 years of amendments to the CPRA"). Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 3 - clarify aspects of Section 6254(f), but they are not referenced in, or located 1 in proximity to, Section 6254(f).13 2 Other CPRA provisions are buried amongst unrelated material. Section 3 6254.7(c), governing records of a housing or building violation, is a good 4 example. It could easily be overlooked, because it is located in the middle of 5 Section 6254.7, surrounded by pollution-related material. 6 To place new material where it seemed to belong, the Legislature has at 7 times resorted to unsystematic decimal numbering (e.g., Sections 6254.1, 8 6254.10, 6254.4.5). This is potentially confusing, because it is difficult to 9 determine the proper sequence of those code sections and thus can be 10 difficult to find them. 11 At other times, the Legislature has added new material on a subject to an 12 already overlong statute that addresses the same subject and other topics. 13 This necessitates cumbersome labeling, such as Section 6254(f)(4)(B)(ii)(I). 14 Such labeling makes it hard for CPRA users to readily refer to the material 15 in question. 16 Problems like these impede fulfillment of the purposes underlying the CPRA. 17 History and Purposes of the Commission's Study 18 In 2016, the Legislature recognized and decided to address the problems 19 described above. That year, Assembly Member Chau authored the biennial 20 legislative resolution regarding topics assigned to the Commission for study. At 21 the request of the Assembly Committee on Judiciary, he included the following 22 new study in the resolution: 23 Resolved, That the Legislature authorizes and requests that the California Law 24 Revision Commission study, report on, and prepare recommended legislation as 25 soon as possible, considering the commission's preexisting duties and workload 26 demands, concerning the revision of the portions of the California Public Records 27 Act and related provisions, and that this legislation shall accomplish all of the 28 following objectives: 29 (1) Reduce the length and complexity of current sections. 30 (2) Avoid unnecessary cross-references. 31 (3) Neither expand nor contract the scope of existing exemptions to the general 32 rule that records are open to the public pursuant to the current provisions of the 33 Public Records Act. 34 (4) To the extent compatible with (3), use terms with common definitions. 35 (5) Organize the existing provisions in such a way that similar provisions are 36 located in close proximity to one another. 37 (6) Eliminate duplicative provisions. 38 13. Similarly, Section 6254(l) is a CPRA exemption for "[c]orrespondence of and to the Governor or employees of the Governor's office or in the custody of or maintained by the Governor's Legal Affairs Secretary." Sections 6268 and 6268.5 also concern access to the Governor's records, but they are not referenced in, or located in proximity to, Section 6254(l). Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 4 - (7) Clearly express legislative intent without any change in the substantive 1 provisions ....14 2 An analysis for the Assembly Committee on Judiciary explained the need for 3 such a study: 4 The CPRA, signed into law in 1968 as a general record keeping law, allows the 5 public to monitor government activity. Since the enactment of the CPRA, it has 6 been amended multiple times to exempt certain records. ... Due to the multiple 7 changes to the statute, the CPRA has become difficult for the public to 8 understand.15 9 Similarly, an analysis for the Senate Committee on Judiciary explained: 10 Because of nearly 50 years of amendments to the CPRA, the CPRA has become 11 more difficult to understand. Making it easier for the public to understand their 12 rights to access government information will arguably lead to more access to 13 public records and more government accountability.16 14 The Legislature passed the resolution near the end of the legislative session 15 without anyone voting against it. 16 Soon afterwards, the Commission began examining the CPRA as requested. It 17 has been steadily building this tentative recommendation since then. 18 Scope of Study 19 As originally introduced, the legislative resolution instructed the Commission to 20 "study, report on, and prepare recommended legislation ... concerning the revision 21 of the portions of the Government Code relating to public records ...."17 It was not 22 clear whether the study was to encompass all Government Code provisions 23 relating to public records, or only those relating to inspection of public records. It 24 was also uncertain at best whether the Commission could examine any related 25 provisions located outside the Government Code, such as statutes that cross-refer 26 to the CPRA. 27 Later, however, the resolution was amended to instruct the Commission to 28 "study, report on, and prepare recommended legislation ... concerning the revision 29 of ... the California Public Records Act and related provisions ...."18 Given this 30 amendment, the Commission's authority appears to be limited to public records 31 14. 2016 Cal. Stat. res. ch. 150 (ACR 148 (Chau)); see also 2018 Cal. Stat. res. ch. 158 (SCR 91 (Roth)). 15. Assembly Committee on Judiciary Analysis of ACR 148 (April 19, 2016), p. 3 (emphasis added). 16. Senate Committee on Judiciary Analysis of ACR 148 (June 14, 2016), p. 4 (emphasis added). 17. ACR 148 (Chau), as introduced on March 3, 2016 (emphasis added). 18. Due to what appears to have been an inadvertent error, the 2016 resolution referred to "the portions of the California Public Records Act and related provisions ...." See 2016 Cal. Stat. res. ch. 150 (ACR 148 (Chau)). The italicized language was deleted when the Commission's authority to study the CPRA was reaffirmed in 2018. See 2018 Cal. Stat. res. ch. 158 (SCR 91 (Roth)). Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 5 - inspection law, not other aspects of public records law (e.g., laws governing 1 retention of public records19 or criminalizing conduct relating to public records20). 2 Importantly, however, the Commission's authority does not appear to be 3 restricted to the Government Code. Rather, the Commission may examine 4 provisions located elsewhere, so long as they relate to the CPRA. The Commission 5 is thus authorized not only to prepare a recodification of the CPRA, but also to 6 recommend conforming revisions of the many statutes throughout the codes that 7 cross-refer to the CPRA. 8 Whether the Commission is authorized to go beyond conforming revisions and 9 suggest additional clean-up of record inspection laws other than the CPRA (e.g., 10 the Richard McKee Transparency Act of 201121) is not obvious from the language 11 of the resolution requesting this study. To move the study forward promptly, and 12 keep any resulting legislation manageable in size, the Commission has not done 13 so. 14 Nonsubstantive Reform 15 In directing the Commission to study the CPRA, the Legislature said that the 16 Commission's recommended legislation should "[c]learly express legislative intent 17 without any change in the substantive provisions" and "[n]either expand nor 18 contract the scope of existing exemptions to the general rule that records are open 19 to the public pursuant to the current provisions of the Public Records Act."22 The 20 Legislature thus made clear that the Commission's work was to be entirely 21 nonsubstantive in nature. 22 The Commission took extreme care to abide by that limitation in preparing this 23 tentative recommendation. The specific measures it took to prevent any 24 substantive change are described below. 25 Objective and Participatory Study Process 26 The Commission's study process is well-suited to the development of a 27 nonsubstantive reform of the CPRA, for the following reasons: 28 The Commission is neutral and objective, with a long history of nonpartisan 29 statutory reforms.23 30 19. See, e.g., Sections 9080 (legislative records), 12220-12237 (State Archives), 14740-14746 (State Records Storage Act), 26201-26202.6 (county records), 34090-34090.8 (city records), 68150-68152 (trial court records). See also Sections 12270-12279 (State Records Management Act). 20. See, e.g., Sections 6200-6203.6 21. Sections 92950-92961. 22. 2016 Cal. Stat. res. ch. 150 (emphasis added). 23. For a listing of reforms that have been enacted on the Commission's recommendation, see the most recent version of its Annual Report (available at www.clrc.ca.gov). Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 6 - The Commission is experienced in drafting legislation to recodify a 1 complex body of law without substantive change.24 2 The Commission actively solicits input from affected individuals and 3 interest groups. It carefully considers each comment and often makes 4 revisions in response to concerns raised. 5 In proposing a statutory reform, the Commission prepares a thorough report 6 that explains the purpose and effect of the reform. The report also includes a 7 complete draft of the proposed legislation and accompanying commentary, a 8 detailed table of contents, and a table showing the disposition of every 9 affected section. This report facilitates public review of the proposed 10 reform. 11 The Commission's work is transparent. All materials are publicly 12 distributed. All deliberations are conducted at open public meetings.25 13 Commission Comments 14 In preparing a recommendation, the Commission drafts an explanatory 15 "Comment" for every section that is added, amended, or repealed.26 A Comment 16 indicates the derivation of the section and often explains its relation to other law. 17 Virtually every Comment in this tentative recommendation expressly states that 18 a proposed new code section continues an existing code section "without 19 substantive change."27 That is important because upon enactment of the 20 Commission's recommendation, the Comment would become a key aid in 21 determining legislative intent. 22 On completion of a final recommendation in this study, the Commission will 23 present the full recommendation, including the Comments, to the Legislature and 24 the Governor. If a bill is introduced to implement the recommendation, the 25 Commission will provide the full recommendation to each member of every policy 26 committee that reviews the bill. 27 24. See, e.g., Nonsubstantive Reorganization of Deadly Weapon Statutes, 38 Cal. L. Revision Comm'n Reports 217 (2009) (enacted as 2010 Cal. Stat. chs. 178 & 711, with support from both gun control and gun rights groups); Civil Discovery: Nonsubstantive Reform, 33 Cal. L. Revision Comm'n Reports 789 (2003) (enacted as 2004 Cal. Stat. ch. 182, without any "no" votes). 25. For a more thorough description of the Commission's study process, see CLRC Staff Memorandum 2012-1; B. Gaal, Evidence Legislation in California, 36 Sw. U. L. Rev. 561 (2008); see also http://www.clrc.ca.gov/Menu5_about/process.html. 26. In the proposed legislation presented in this tentative recommendation, the Comment for each proposed code section appears immediately after the code section. 27. For example, the Comment to proposed Section 7921.705 states that it "continues former Section 6264 without substantive change." The Comment refers to the existing provision as "former Section 6264" (rather than "Section 6264") because the Comment would be used after enactment of the proposed law and repeal of the existing version of the CPRA. Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 7 - Commission materials that have been placed before and considered by the 1 Legislature are considered evidence of legislative intent,28 and are entitled to great 2 weight in construing statutes.29 The materials are a key interpretive aid for 3 practitioners as well as courts,30 and courts may judicially notice and rely on 4 them.31 Courts at all levels of the state32 and federal33 judicial systems use 5 Commission materials to construe statutes enacted on Commission 6 recommendation.34 7 The Commission's Comments to the proposed legislation in this study would 8 thus help to demonstrate that the legislation constitutes a purely nonsubstantive 9 recodification of the CPRA. 10 28. Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 8 - Statements of Legislative Intent 1 The proposed law would be known as the "CPRA Recodification Act of 2 2020."35 It includes several codified provisions that would expressly state the 3 purpose and effect of the recodification. 4 Proposed Section 7920.100 is a general statement regarding the nonsubstantive 5 effect of the recodification: 6 7920.100. Nothing in the CPRA Recodification Act of 2020 is intended to 7 substantively change the law relating to inspection of public records. The act is 8 intended to be entirely nonsubstantive in effect. Every provision of this division 9 and every other provision of this act, including, without limitation, every cross-10 reference in every provision of the act, shall be interpreted consistent with the 11 nonsubstantive intent of the act. 12 Proposed Section 7920.105 would make clear that a provision of the proposed 13 law is intended as a restatement and continuation of the provision that it restates, 14 rather than a new enactment, and that any reference to a restated provision is 15 deemed to include a reference to the section that restates it (and vice versa): 16 7920.105. (a) A provision of this division, or any other provision of the CPRA 17 Recodification Act of 2020, insofar as it is substantially the same as a previously 18 existing provision relating to the same subject matter, shall be considered as a 19 restatement and continuation thereof and not as a new enactment. 20 (b) A reference in a statute to a previously existing provision that is restated 21 and continued in this division, or in any other provision of the CPRA 22 Recodification Act of 2020, shall, unless a contrary intent appears, be deemed a 23 reference to the restatement and continuation. 24 (c) A reference in a statute to a provision of this division, or any other 25 provision of the CPRA Recodification Act of 2020, which is substantially the 26 same as a previously existing provision, shall, unless a contrary intent appears, be 27 deemed to include a reference to the previously existing provision. 28 Another provision (proposed Section 7920.110) would make clear that 29 restatement of an existing CPRA provision is not intended to have any effect, 30 positive or negative, on a judicial interpretation of the restated provision: 31 7920.110. (a) A judicial decision interpreting a previously existing provision is 32 relevant in interpreting any provision of this division, or any other provision of 33 the CPRA Recodification Act of 2020, which restates and continues that 34 previously existing provision. 35 (b) However, in enacting the CPRA Recodification Act of 2020, the Legislature 36 has not evaluated the correctness of any judicial decision interpreting a provision 37 affected by the act. 38 (c) The CPRA Recodification Act of 2020 is not intended to, and does not, 39 reflect any assessment of any judicial decision interpreting any provision affected 40 by the act. 41 35. See proposed Section 7920.005 infra. Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 9 - Proposed Section 7920.115 sets forth similar rules with respect to an interpretation 1 advanced in an Attorney General opinion, because such opinions are particularly 2 common and influential in this area of the law. 3 Lastly, proposed Section 7920.120 would make clear that restatement of a 4 CPRA provision is not intended to have any effect, positive or negative, on a 5 judicial decision or Attorney General opinion on the constitutionality of the 6 restated provision: 7 7920.120. (a) A judicial decision or Attorney General opinion on the 8 constitutionality of a previously existing provision is relevant in determining the 9 constitutionality of any provision of this division, or any other provision of the 10 CPRA Recodification Act of 2020, which restates and continues that previously 11 existing provision. 12 (b) However, in enacting the CPRA Recodification Act of 2020, the Legislature 13 has not evaluated the constitutionality of any provision affected by the act, or the 14 correctness of any judicial decision or Attorney General opinion on the 15 constitutionality of any provision affected by the act. 16 (c) The CPRA Recodification Act of 2020 is not intended to, and does not, 17 reflect any determination of the constitutionality of any provision affected by the 18 act. 19 The provisions discussed above would establish that enactment of the proposed 20 recodification should not be viewed as acquiescence in any court case or Attorney 21 General opinion construing the CPRA, or as an indication that the Legislature 22 assessed the constitutionality of each recodified section in enacting the 23 recodification. The proposed law would take no stand and have no effect on such 24 matters. 25 In addition to these codified statements of legislative intent, the proposed 26 legislation includes an uncodified provision that sets forth the following legislative 27 findings: 28 This act would recodify the California Public Records Act (Sections 6250 to 29 6276.48, inclusive, of the Government Code) in a more user-friendly manner 30 without changing its substance, and make conforming revisions. Consistent with 31 subdivision (b) of Section 3 of Article I of the California Constitution, the 32 Legislature finds and declares: 33 (1) This act continues the existing substantive balance between the public's 34 right of access to information concerning the conduct of public business and 35 competing interests. This act does not impose any new limitation on the public's 36 right of access, which would require findings demonstrating the interest protected 37 by the new limitation and the need for protecting that interest. 38 (2) By making the California Public Records Act more user-friendly, this act 39 furthers the public's right of access to information concerning the conduct of 40 public business. 41 These legislative findings would further reinforce the nonsubstantive nature of the 42 reform. 43 Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 10 - Conservative Drafting 1 In preparing this tentative recommendation, the Commission used a conservative 2 drafting approach. It stuck closely to the existing statutory text, to further 3 minimize the risk of a substantive change. 4 The Commission was especially cautious with Section 6254(f), the exemption 5 pertaining to law enforcement records. Although that provision is particularly 6 complex and difficult to understand, the Commission refrained from attempting to 7 rephrase it more clearly.36 Instead, to avoid generating concerns about a 8 substantive change, the proposed legislation would relocate the substance of 9 Section 6254(f) in a new article almost verbatim.37 An adjacent article would 10 contain the substance of the related provisions previously mentioned (Sections 11 6254.30 and 6262).38 12 Legislative Process 13 After the Commission completes its study process and issues a final 14 recommendation, the proposed law would be scrutinized carefully in the 15 legislative process, just like any other bill. This would serve as a final safeguard 16 against any substantive change in the law. 17 Drafting Approach 18 As discussed above, the Commission used a conservative drafting approach in 19 preparing this tentative recommendation. Other significant drafting techniques and 20 decisions are described below. 21 Location of the Proposed Law 22 The CPRA is currently codified as "Chapter 3.5. Inspection of Public Records" 23 in "Division 7. Miscellaneous" in "Title 1. General" in the Government Code. It is 24 divided into two articles: 25 "Article 1. General Provisions,"39 which contains the heart of the CPRA. 26 "Article 2. Other Exemptions from Disclosure,"40 which contains a list of 27 CPRA exemptions ("the CPRA index"), most of which are located outside 28 the CPRA. 29 To effectively reorganize the CPRA, it would be helpful to be able to divide the 30 material now in "Article 1. General Provisions" into various subcategories, placing 31 36. Similarly, the Commission refrained from addressing the apparently minor substantive issues that are listed at the end of its report in "Appendix B. Minor Clean-Up Issues for Possible Future Legislative Attention." 37. See proposed Sections 7923.600-7923.625 infra. 38. See proposed Sections 7923.650-7923.655 infra. 39. Sections 6250-6270.7. 40. Sections 6275-6276.48. Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 11 - similar provisions together. That would further the legislative objective to 1 "[o]rganize the existing provisions in such a way that similar provisions are 2 located in close proximity to one another."41 3 In the hierarchy of the Government Code, an article is the lowest level heading 4 used to organize code sections. Because an article cannot be further subdivided, it 5 would be difficult to effectively reorganize the CPRA in its current code location. 6 Instead, the proposed law would repeal the existing CPRA and recodify its 7 substance in a new division (Division 10) of Title 1 of the Government Code. This 8 would make it possible to divide that material into parts,42 chapters, and articles — 9 enough subcategories to create a user-friendly organizational scheme.43 10 Structure of the Proposed Law 11 New Division 10 would be divided into six parts, as follows: 12 Part 1. Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 14 - Numbering System 1 Throughout the proposed legislation, the Commission used a 3-digit decimal 2 system for numbering code sections (e.g., Section 7920.000). The Commission 3 also left gaps in the numbering, to allow ready insertion of new statutory material 4 in an appropriate location if needed in the future. 5 This numbering approach will prevent confusion regarding the proper 6 sequencing of code sections. It will also promote logical, user-friendly 7 organization as the CPRA continues to evolve. 8 Short, Simple Sections 9 The legislative resolution on this study instructs the Commission to "[r]educe 10 the length and complexity of current sections."78 The CPRA currently contains a 11 number of long and complicated sections, most notably Section 6254, which spans 12 eight singled-spaced pages if printed from the Legislative Counsel's website 13 (5,583 words), with subdivisions labeled from (a) to (z) followed by (aa) to (ad), 14 some of which are split into paragraphs, subparagraphs, and even unnumbered 15 provisions.79 16 Excessively long sections can obscure relevant details of law, especially if a 17 single section addresses several different subjects. A better approach is to divide 18 the law into a larger number of smaller sections, with each section limited to a 19 single subject. 20 Short sections have numerous advantages. They enhance readability and 21 understanding of the law, and make it easier to locate and refer to pertinent 22 material. In contrast to a long section, a short section can be amended without 23 undue technical difficulties80 and new material can be inserted where logically 24 appropriate, facilitating sound development of the law.81 The use of short sections 25 78. 2016 Cal. Stat. res. ch. 150 (ACR 148 (Chau)); see also 2018 Cal. Stat. res. ch. 158 (SCR 91 (Roth)) (reaffirming Commission's authority to study CPRA). 79. Other, less egregious examples in the CPRA include Sections 6253, 6254.2, 6254.18, and 6254.21. 80. The full text of a section must be set forth in any bill amending the section. Joint Rule 10. A lengthy bill entails higher printing costs than a short one. It also takes longer to review. Much of the material may be unrelated to a proposed reform, wasting reviewers' time and potentially injecting additional issues into a simple proposal. Further, the likelihood that two bills will be introduced to amend the same section is greater if a section is long and covers multiple topics than if a section is short and limited to a single topic. If two bills affect the same section and both are enacted, the bill that is signed last generally prevails over the other bill, rendering it a nullity. Section 9605. This can be avoided by double-jointing the bills or including other language to address the conflict. Taking such steps entails expense and effort, however, and introduces new possibilities for errors. 81. In amending a short section, the Legislature is unhampered by constraints such as overlong paragraphs and lack of available subparts. This promotes clear and straightforward drafting, as opposed to confusing and convoluted provisions. Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 15 - is the preferred drafting technique of the California Code Commission,82 the 1 Legislature,83 the Legislative Counsel,84 and the Law Revision Commission.85 2 For all of the reasons discussed above, the proposed law would divide lengthy 3 sections into shorter and simpler provisions. The number of sections would 4 approximately double, but the word count would not change that much. 5 Signposting in Comments 6 In the proposed legislation, the Comment accompanying each code section 7 would refer to other provisions (particularly within the CPRA) that may be of 8 interest to users.86 This would help CPRA users locate material relevant to their 9 situations. 10 Cross-References 11 The CPRA contains numerous internal cross-references. In the proposed 12 legislation, the Commission updated each such cross-reference to reflect the new 13 numbering scheme in the recodification. 14 To facilitate review of the updated cross-references, this tentative 15 recommendation includes two tables, located immediately after the proposed 16 legislation. One table shows the disposition of each existing code section; the 17 other table shows the derivation of each proposed code section. 18 The CPRA also contains numerous cross-references to statutes located outside 19 the CPRA. The Commission checked each of those cross-references, as well as 20 each of the internal cross-references, in preparing this tentative recommendation. 21 A few of the cross-references in the current version of the CPRA are plainly 22 erroneous. Where the proper cross-reference is obvious, the Commission corrected 23 the cross-reference in the proposed legislation, rather than perpetuating the error. 24 The cross-reference corrections are explained in the accompanying Comments; 25 they are also listed and explained in Appendix A. Where the proper cross-26 reference is not altogether obvious, the Commission left the cross-reference alone, 27 so as not to create a risk of a substantive change. Notes in the tentative 28 recommendation seek input on the problematic cross-references. 29 There are also many code sections located outside the CPRA that cross-refer to 30 one or more provisions within the CPRA. Those cross-references will also need to 31 be conformed to the new numbering scheme in the recodification. The 32 82. Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 16 - Commission will prepare and circulate a separate tentative recommendation with 1 those conforming revisions. 2 Pending and Future Legislation 3 There are pending bills to revise the CPRA in one way or another.87 If one or 4 more of those bills is enacted, the Commission will incorporate the substance of 5 the enacted bill(s) into the proposed recodification, without substantive change. 6 There are also pending bills that would affect provisions that are listed, or 7 should be listed, in the CPRA index.88 If any of those bills is enacted, the 8 Commission will make an appropriate adjustment in the proposed continuation of 9 the CPRA index. 10 When the Commission eventually approves a final recommendation and a 11 legislator introduces a bill to implement that recommendation, there might be 12 conflicts between that bill and other pending bills (i.e., they might try to revise the 13 same code provision in different ways). If so, the Commission will recommend 14 double-jointing amendments or other steps to eliminate the conflicts and 15 coordinate the bills. The Commission will take similar steps with regard to any bill 16 that might bear on the content of the CPRA index. Any such adjustments will be 17 consistent with the nonsubstantive nature of this study. 18 Delayed Operative Date 19 Because of the breadth of the organizational changes that would be made by the 20 proposed legislation, the Commission recommends that it be given a delayed 21 operative date. The proposed legislation includes an uncodified provision to that 22 effect, which would delay the operation of the proposed law by six months (i.e., 23 until July 1, 2021).89 24 This delayed operation would provide time for those who work closely with the 25 affected statutes, including legal publishers, to adjust to the new organizational 26 scheme before it takes effect. The Commission's comments and the disposition 27 and derivation tables in the Commission's report would also help ease the 28 transition. 29 Although the proposed recodification would entail some transitional costs (such 30 as updating manuals and regulations), the Commission believes that the long-term 31 benefits of having a better organized, more user-friendly statutory scheme would 32 87. In general, a bill passed by the Legislature and signed by the Governor becomes operative on January 1 of the year after its enactment. See Cal. Const. art. IV, § 8(c)(1); Gov't Code § 9600(a). A draft of an official Commission "Comment" follows each proposed code section in the 1 proposed recodification. Such Comments will be included in any final recommendation. The 2 Comments indicate the source of each recodified code section (or provision within the code section) 3 and describe how the recodified code section (or provision) compares with prior law. Courts have 4 routinely held that the Commission's Comments are evidence of legislative intent with regard to 5 any legislation that implements a Commission recommendation. 6 There is a "disposition table" at the end of the proposed recodification. It summarizes, in tabular 7 form, the disposition of every provision of the existing code that has been included in this proposed 8 recodification. 9 There is also a "derivation table" at the end of the proposed recodification. It summarizes, in 10 tabular form, the statutory derivation of every new code provision in this proposed recodification. 11 Some provisions in this draft are followed by a "Note." Most of the Notes are intended to be 12 temporary and will not be part of the Commission's final recommendation. In general, the Notes 13 serve to flag issues requiring special attention or treatment. 14 Almost all of the proposed provisions would be located in the Government Code. All references 15 are to the Government Code unless otherwise indicated. 16 The Commission welcomes public comment on any issue relating to the content of this draft or 17 any other aspect of its ongoing CPRA Clean-Up study. (Emphasis added). 44 It seems improbable that the Legislature intended this provision to include as a "public safety 45 official" only an employee who supervises inmates in one of the enumerated facilities for adults 46 and in one of the enumerated facilities for juveniles. Proposed Section 7920.535(g) would refer 47 instead to an employee "who supervises inmates in a city police department, a county sheriff's 48 office, the Department of the California Highway Patrol, federal, state, or a local detention facility, 49 or a local juvenile hall, camp, ranch, or home...." (a) Each agency, upon a request for a copy of records, shall, within 10 33 days from receipt of the request, determine whether the request, in whole or in part, 34 seeks copies of disclosable public records in the possession of the agency and shall 35 promptly notify the person making the request of the determination and the reasons 36 therefor. (a) When a member of the public requests to inspect a public record or 31 obtain a copy of a public record, the public agency, in order to assist the member of 32 the public make a focused and effective request that reasonably describes an 33 identifiable record or records, shall do all of the following, to the extent reasonable 34 under the circumstances: 35 (1) Assist the member of the public to identify records and information that are 36 responsive to the request or to the purpose of the request, if stated. 37 (2) Describe the information technology and physical location in which the 38 records exist. 39 (3) Provide suggestions for overcoming any practical basis for denying access to 40 the records or information sought. 41 (b) The requirements of paragraph (1) of subdivision (a) shall be deemed to have 42 been satisfied if the public agency is unable to identify the requested information 43 after making a reasonable effort to elicit additional clarifying information from the 44 requester that will help identify the record or records. 45 Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 57 - (c) The requirements of subdivision (a) are in addition to any action required of a 1 public agency by Article 1 (commencing with Section 7922.500) or Article 2 2 (commencing with Section 7922.525). 3 Comment. If a local agency, except a school district, maintains an Internet 35 Resource, including, but not limited to, an Internet Web site, Internet Web page, or 36 Internet Web portal, which the local agency describes or titles as "open data," and 37 the local agency voluntarily posts a public record on that Internet Resource, the local 38 agency shall post the public record in an open format that meets all of the following 39 requirements: 40 (a) Retrievable, downloadable, indexable, and electronically searchable by 41 commonly used Internet search applications. 42 (b) Platform independent and machine readable. 43 Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 61 - (c) Available to the public free of charge and without any restriction that would 1 impede the reuse or redistribution of the public record. 2 (d) Retains the data definitions and structure present when the data was compiled, 3 if applicable. 4 Comment. "Enterprise system" 26 7922.700. For purposes of this article: 27 (a) "Enterprise system" means a software application or computer system that 28 satisfies all of the following conditions: 29 (1) It collects, stores, exchanges, and analyzes information that the agency uses. 30 (2) It is a multidepartmental system or a system that contains information 31 collected about the public. 32 (3) It is a system of record. 33 (b) An "enterprise system" does not include any of the following: 34 (1) Information technology security systems, including firewalls and other 35 cybersecurity systems. 36 (2) Physical access control systems, employee identification management 37 systems, video monitoring, and other physical control systems. 38 (3) Infrastructure and mechanical control systems, including those that control or 39 manage street lights, electrical, natural gas, or water or sewer functions. 40 (4) Systems related to 911 dispatch and operation or emergency services. 41 (5) Systems that would be restricted from disclosure pursuant to Section 42 7929.210. 43 Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 62 - (6) The specific records that the information technology system collects, stores, 1 exchanges, or analyzes. 2 Comment. Disclosure of information relating to complaints or requests for assistance 5 7923.615. (a) Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, a state or local 6 law enforcement agency shall make public, subject to the restrictions imposed by 7 Section 841.5 of the Penal Code, the time, substance, and location of all complaints 8 or requests for assistance received by the agency, and the time and nature of the 9 response thereto, except to the extent that disclosure of a particular item of 10 information would endanger the safety of a person involved in an investigation or 11 the successful completion of the investigation or a related investigation. To the 12 extent the information regarding crimes alleged or committed or any other incident 13 investigated is recorded, this includes all of the following: 14 (1) The time, date, and location of occurrence. 15 (2) The time and date of the report. 16 (3) The name and age of the victim. 17 (4) The factual circumstances surrounding the crime or incident. 18 (5) A general description of any injuries, property, or weapons involved. 19 (b)(1) The name of a victim of any crime defined by Section 220, 261, 261.5, 262, 20 264, 264.1, or former Section 288a of, the Penal Code may be 23 withheld at the victim's request, or at the request of the victim's parent or guardian 24 if the victim is a minor. 25 (2) When a person is the victim of more than one crime, information disclosing 26 that the person is a victim of a crime defined in any of the sections of the Penal Code 27 set forth in this article may be deleted at the request of the victim, or the victim's 28 parent or guardian if the victim is a minor, in making the report of the crime, or of 29 any crime or incident accompanying the crime, available to the public in compliance 30 with the requirements of this section. 31 (c)(1) Subject to the restrictions imposed by Section 841.5 of the Penal Code, the 32 names and images of a victim of human trafficking, as defined in Section 236.1 of 33 the Penal Code, and of that victim's immediate family, other than a family member 34 who is charged with a criminal offense arising from the same incident, may be 35 withheld at the victim's request until the investigation or any subsequent 36 prosecution is complete. 37 (2) For purposes of this article, "immediate family" shall have the same meaning 38 as that provided in paragraph (3) of subdivision (b) of Section 422.4 of the Penal 39 Code. 40 Comment. Video or audio recording relating to critical incident 1 7923.625. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, commencing July 2 1, 2019, a video or audio recording that relates to a critical incident, as defined in 3 subdivision (e), may be withheld only as follows: 4 (a)(1) During an active criminal or administrative investigation, disclosure of a 5 recording related to a critical incident may be delayed for no longer than 45 calendar 6 days after the date the agency knew or reasonably should have known about the 7 incident, if, based on the facts and circumstances depicted in the recording, 8 disclosure would substantially interfere with the investigation, such as by 9 endangering the safety of a witness or a confidential source. If an agency delays 10 disclosure pursuant to this section, the agency shall provide in writing to the 11 requester the specific basis for the agency's determination that disclosure would 12 substantially interfere with the investigation and the estimated date for disclosure. 13 (2) After 45 days from the date the agency knew or reasonably should have known 14 about the incident, and up to one year from that date, the agency may continue to 15 delay disclosure of a recording if the agency demonstrates that disclosure would 16 substantially interfere with the investigation. After one year from the date the 17 agency knew or reasonably should have known about the incident, the agency may 18 continue to delay disclosure of a recording only if the agency demonstrates by clear 19 and convincing evidence that disclosure would substantially interfere with the 20 investigation. If an agency delays disclosure pursuant to this paragraph, the agency 21 shall promptly provide in writing to the requester the specific basis for the agency's 22 determination that the interest in preventing interference with an active investigation 23 outweighs the public interest in disclosure and provide the estimated date for the 24 disclosure. The agency shall reassess withholding and notify the requester every 30 25 days. A recording withheld by the agency shall be disclosed promptly when the 26 specific basis for withholding is resolved. 27 (b)(1) If the agency demonstrates, on the facts of the particular case, that the 28 public interest in withholding a video or audio recording clearly outweighs the 29 public interest in disclosure because the release of the recording would, based on 30 the facts and circumstances depicted in the recording, violate the reasonable 31 expectation of privacy of a subject depicted in the recording, the agency shall 32 provide in writing to the requester the specific basis for the expectation of privacy 33 and the public interest served by withholding the recording and may use redaction 34 technology, including blurring or distorting images or audio, to obscure those 35 specific portions of the recording that protect that interest. However, the redaction 36 shall not interfere with the viewer's ability to fully, completely, and accurately 37 comprehend the events captured in the recording and the recording shall not 38 otherwise be edited or altered. 39 (2) Except as provided in paragraph (3), if the agency demonstrates that the 40 reasonable expectation of privacy of a subject depicted in the recording cannot 41 adequately be protected through redaction as described in paragraph (1) and that 42 interest outweighs the public interest in disclosure, the agency may withhold the 43 Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 77 - recording from the public, except that the recording, either redacted as provided in 1 paragraph (1) or unredacted, shall be disclosed promptly, upon request, to any of 2 the following: 3 (A) The subject of the recording whose privacy is to be protected, or the subject's 4 authorized representative. 5 (B) If the subject is a minor, the parent or legal guardian of the subject whose 6 privacy is to be protected. 7 (C) If the subject whose privacy is to be protected is deceased, an heir, 8 beneficiary, designated immediate family member, or authorized legal 9 representative of the deceased subject whose privacy is to be protected. 10 (3) If disclosure pursuant to paragraph (2) would substantially interfere with an 11 active criminal or administrative investigation, the agency shall provide in writing 12 to the requester the specific basis for the agency's determination that disclosure 13 would substantially interfere with the investigation, and provide the video or audio 14 recording. Thereafter, the recording may be withheld by the agency for 45 calendar 15 days, subject to extensions as set forth in paragraph (2) of subdivision (a). 16 (c) An agency may provide greater public access to video or audio recordings than 17 the minimum standards set forth in this section. 18 (d) For purposes of this section, a peace officer does not include any peace officer 19 employed by the Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation. 20 (e) For purposes of this section, a video or audio recording relates to a critical 21 incident if it depicts any of the following incidents: 22 (1) An incident involving the discharge of a firearm at a person by a peace officer 23 or custodial officer. 24 (2) An incident in which the use of force by a peace officer or custodial officer 25 against a person resulted in death or in great bodily injury. 26 (f) This section does not alter, limit, or negate any other rights, remedies, or 27 obligations with respect to public records regarding an incident other than a critical 28 incident as described in subdivision (e). 29 Comment. Video and audio recordings 7 7923.750. (a) This division does not require disclosure of a video or audio 8 recording that was created during the commission or investigation of the crime of 9 rape, incest, sexual assault, domestic violence, or child abuse that depicts the face, 10 intimate body part, or voice of a victim of the incident depicted in the recording. An 11 agency shall justify withholding such a video or audio recording by demonstrating, 12 pursuant to Section 7922.000 and subdivision (a) of Section 7922.540, that on the 13 facts of the particular case, the public interest served by not disclosing the recording 14 clearly outweighs the public interest served by disclosure of the recording. 15 (b) When balancing the public interests as required by this section, an agency shall 16 consider both of the following: 17 (1) The constitutional right to privacy of the person or persons depicted in the 18 recording. 19 (2) Whether the potential harm to the victim caused by disclosing the recording 20 may be mitigated by redacting the recording to obscure images showing intimate 21 body parts and personally identifying characteristics of the victim or by distorting 22 portions of the recording containing the victim's voice, provided that the redaction 23 does not prevent a viewer from being able to fully and accurately perceive the events 24 captured on the recording. The recording shall not otherwise be edited or altered. 25 (c) A victim of a crime described in subdivision (a) who is a subject of a recording, 26 the parent or legal guardian of a minor subject, a deceased subject's next of kin, or 27 a subject's legally authorized designee, shall be permitted to inspect the recording 28 and to obtain a copy of the recording. Disclosure under this subdivision does not 29 require that the record be made available to the public pursuant to Section 7921.505. 30 (d) Nothing in this section shall be construed to affect any other exemption 31 provided by this division. 32 Comment. Data submitted and designated as trade secret 1 7924.305. (a) The Director of Pesticide Regulation, upon the Director's initiative, 2 or upon receipt of a request pursuant to this division for the release of data submitted 3 and designated as a trade secret by a registrant or applicant, shall determine whether 4 any or all of the data so submitted is a properly designated trade secret. In order to 5 assure that the interested public has an opportunity to obtain and review pesticide 6 safety and efficacy data and to comment prior to the expiration of the public 7 comment period on a proposed pesticide registration, the director shall provide 8 notice to interested persons when an application for registration enters the 9 registration evaluation process. 10 (b) If the director determines that the data is not a trade secret, the director shall 11 notify the registrant or applicant by certified mail. 12 (c) The registrant or applicant shall have 30 days after receipt of this notification 13 to provide the director with a complete justification and statement of the grounds on 14 which the trade secret privilege is claimed. This justification and statement shall be 15 submitted by certified mail. 16 (d) The director shall determine whether the data is protected as a trade secret 17 within 15 days after receipt of the justification and statement or, if no justification 18 and statement is filed, within 45 days of the original notice. The director shall notify 19 the registrant or applicant and any party who has requested the data pursuant to this 20 division of that determination by certified mail. If the director determines that the 21 data is not protected as a trade secret, the final notice shall also specify a date, not 22 sooner than 15 days after the date of mailing of the final notice, when the data shall 23 be available to any person requesting information pursuant to Section 7924.300. 24 (e) This article does not prohibit any person from maintaining a civil action for 25 wrongful disclosure of a trade secret. 26 (f) "Trade secret" means data that is nondisclosable under paragraph (1) of 27 subsection (d) of Section 10 of the federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide 28 Act (7 U.S.C. Sec. 136h(d)(1)). 29 Comment. Prohibition on disclosure of application or registration information to person 26 with specified foreign connection 27 7924.310. (a) Unless the applicant or registrant consents to disclosure of 28 information that the applicant or registrant submits to the state pursuant to Article 4 29 (commencing with Section 12811) of Chapter 2 of Division 7 of the Food and 30 Agricultural Code, the Director of Pesticide Regulation shall not knowingly disclose 31 any of that information to any of the following: 32 (1) An officer, employee, or agent of any business or other entity engaged in the 33 production, sale, or distribution of pesticides in a country other than the United 34 States, or in a country in addition to the United States. 35 (2) Any other person who intends to deliver this information to any foreign or 36 multi-national business or entity. 37 (b) To implement this section, the director shall require a person requesting 38 information described in subdivision (a) to sign the following affirmation: 39 AFFIRMATION OF STATUS 40 This affirmation is required by Article 1 (commencing with Section 7924.310) of 41 Chapter 3 of Part 5 of Division 10 of Title 1 of the Government Code. 42 I have requested access to information submitted to the Department of Pesticide 43 Regulation (or previously submitted to the Department of Food and Agriculture) by 44 Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 90 - a pesticide applicant or registrant pursuant to the California Food and Agricultural 1 Code. I hereby affirm all of the following statements: 2 (1) I do not seek access to the information for purposes of delivering it or offering 3 it for sale to any business or other entity, including the business or entity of which I 4 am an officer, employee, or agent, engaged in the production, sale, or distribution 5 of pesticides in a country other than the United States or in a country in addition to 6 the United States, or to an officer, employee, or agent of such a business or entity. 7 (2) I will not purposefully deliver or negligently cause the data to be delivered to 8 a business or entity specified in paragraph (1) or its officers, employees, or agents. 9 I am aware that I may be subject to criminal penalties under Section 118 of the 10 Penal Code if I make any statement of material facts knowing that the statement is 11 false or if I willfully conceal any material fact. 12 ___________________________ _____________________________ 13 Name of Requester Name of Requester's Organization 14 ___________________________ _____________________________ 15 Signature of Requester Address of Requester 16 _____ ______________ _____________________________ 17 Date Request No. Telephone Number of Requester 18 19 ___________________________ 20 Name, Address, and Telephone 21 Number of Requester's Client if 22 the requester has requested access 23 to the information on behalf of 24 someone other than the requester 25 or the requester's organization 26 listed above. 27 (c) Section 118 of the Penal Code applies to any affirmation made pursuant to this 28 article. 29 Comment. (a) Any information, analysis, plan, or specification that discloses the 39 nature, extent, quantity, or degree of an air contaminant or other pollution that any 40 article, machine, equipment, or other contrivance will produce, which any air 41 pollution control district or air quality management district, or any other state or 42 local agency or district, requires any applicant to provide before the applicant builds, 43 erects, alters, replaces, operates, sells, rents, or uses the article, machine, equipment, 44 or other contrivance, is a public record. 45 Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 96 - (b) All air or other pollution monitoring data, including data compiled from a 1 stationary source, are public records. 2 (c) Except as otherwise provided in subdivision (d) and Chapter 3 (commencing 3 with Section 99150) of Part 65 of the Education Code, a trade secret is not a public 4 record under this section or Section 7924.700. 5 (d) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, all air pollution emission data, 6 including those emission data that constitute trade secrets as defined in subdivision 7 (f), are public records. Data used to calculate emission data are not emission data 8 for the purposes of this subdivision and data that constitute trade secrets and that are 9 used to calculate emission data are not public records. 10 (e) Data used to calculate the costs of obtaining emissions offsets are not public 11 records. At the time that an air pollution control district or air quality management 12 district issues a permit to construct to an applicant who is required to obtain offsets 13 pursuant to district rules and regulations, data obtained from the applicant consisting 14 of the year the offset transaction occurred, the amount of offsets purchased, by 15 pollutant, and the total cost, by pollutant, of the offsets purchased is a public record. 16 If an application is denied, the data shall not be a public record. 17 (f) As used in this section, "trade secret" may include, but is not limited to, any 18 formula, plan, pattern, process, tool, mechanism, compound, procedure, production 19 data, or compilation of information that satisfies all of the following requirements: 20 (1) It is not patented. 21 (2) It is known only to certain individuals within a commercial concern who are 22 using it to fabricate, produce, or compound an article of trade or a service having 23 commercial value. 24 (3) It gives its user an opportunity to obtain a business advantage over competitors 25 who do not know or use it. 26 Comment. Reproductive Health Services Facility 38 § 7926.400. Definitions 39 7926.400. For purposes of this article, the following terms have the following 40 meanings: 41 (a) "Contractor" means an individual or entity that contracts with a reproductive 42 health services facility for services related to patient care. 43 (b) "Personal information" means any of the following information related to an 44 individual that is maintained by a public agency: 45 Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 113 - (1) Social security number. 1 (2) Physical description. 2 (3) Home address. 3 (4) Home telephone number. 4 (5) Statements of personal worth or personal financial data filed pursuant to 5 Section 7925.005. 6 (6) Personal medical history. 7 (7) Employment history. 8 (8) Electronic mail address. 9 (9) Information that reveals any electronic network location or identity. 10 (c) "Public agency" means all of the following: 11 (1) The Department of Consumer Affairs. 12 (2) The Department of Managed Health Care. 13 (3) The State Department of Health Care Services. 14 (4) The State Department of Public Health. 15 (d) "Reproductive health services facility" means the office of a licensed 16 physician and surgeon whose specialty is family practice, obstetrics, or gynecology, 17 or a licensed clinic, where at least 50 percent of the patients of the physician or the 18 clinic are provided with family planning or abortion services. 19 Comment. (a) In order for this article to apply to an individual who is an employee, 26 volunteer, board member, officer, or contractor of a reproductive health services 27 facility, the individual shall notify the public agency to which the individual's 28 personal information is being submitted or has been submitted that the individual 29 falls within the application of this article. 30 (b) Notification pursuant to subdivision (a) is valid if it complies with all of the 31 following: 32 (1) It is on the official letterhead of the facility. 33 (2) It is clearly separate from any other language present on the same page and is 34 executed by a signature that serves no other purpose than to execute the notification. 35 (3) It is signed and dated by both of the following: 36 (A) The individual whose information is being submitted. 37 (B) The executive officer of the reproductive health services facility or designee 38 of the executive officer. 39 (c) A reproductive health services facility shall retain a copy of all notifications 40 submitted pursuant to this article. 41 Comment. Patron use records of library supported by public funds 1 7927.105. (a) As used in this section, the term "patron use records" includes the 2 following: 3 (1) Any written or electronic record that is used to identify a library patron and is 4 provided by the patron to become eligible to borrow or use books and other 5 materials. This includes, but is not limited to, a patron's name, address, telephone 6 number, or e-mail address. 7 (2) Any written record or electronic transaction that identifies a patron's 8 borrowing information or use of library information resources. This includes, but is 9 not limited to, database search records, borrowing records, class records, and any 10 other personally identifiable uses of library resources information requests, or 11 inquiries. 12 (b) This section does not apply to either of the following: 13 (1) Statistical reports of patron use. 14 (2) Records of fines collected by a library. 15 (c) All patron use records of a library that is in whole or in part supported by 16 public funds shall remain confidential. A public agency, or a private actor that 17 maintains or stores patron use records on behalf of a public agency, shall not 18 disclose those records to any person, local agency, or state agency, except as 19 follows: 20 (1) By a person acting within the scope of the person's duties within the 21 administration of the library. 22 (2) By a person authorized in writing to inspect the records. The authorization 23 shall be from the individual to whom the records pertain. 24 (3) By order of the appropriate superior court. 25 Comment. (a) When the Governor leaves office, either voluntarily or 31 involuntarily, public records in the custody or control of the Governor shall be 32 transferred to the State Archives as soon as practical. 33 (b) Notwithstanding any other law, the Governor, by written instrument, the 34 terms of which shall be made public, may restrict public access to any of the 35 transferred public records, or any other writings the Governor may transfer that have 36 not already been made accessible to the public. 37 (c) With respect to public records, public access, as otherwise provided for by this 38 division, shall not be restricted for a period greater than 50 years or the death of the 39 Governor, whichever is later, nor shall there be any restriction whatsoever with 40 respect to enrolled bill files, press releases, speech files, or writings relating to 41 applications for clemency or extradition in cases that have been closed for a period 42 of at least 25 years. Special rule for Governor who held office between 1974 and 1988 26 7928.010. (a)(1) For a Governor who held office between 1974 and 1988, Section 27 7928.005 does not apply to public records or other writings that were in the 28 Governor's direct custody or control at the time of leaving office, except to the 29 extent that the Governor may voluntarily transfer those records or other writings to 30 the State Archives. 31 (2) Subdivision (a) does not apply to enrolled bill files, press releases, speech files, 32 or writings relating to applications for clemency or extradition. 33 (b)(1) Notwithstanding any other law, the public records and other writings of any 34 Governor who held office between 1974 and 1988 may be transferred to any 35 educational or research institution in California. With respect to public records, 36 however, public access, as otherwise provided for by this division, shall not be 37 restricted for a period greater than 50 years or the death of the Governor, whichever 38 is later. 39 (2) Records or writings shall not be transferred pursuant to this subdivision unless 40 the institution receiving them agrees to maintain, and does maintain, the materials 41 according to commonly accepted archival standards. 42 (3) An institution receiving public records pursuant to this subdivision shall not 43 destroy any of those records without first receiving the written approval of the 44 Secretary of State, as custodian of the State Archives. The Secretary of State may 45 require that the records be placed in the State Archives rather than being destroyed. 46 Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 133 - (4) An institution receiving records or writings pursuant to this subdivision shall 1 allow the Secretary of State, as custodian of the State Archives, to copy, at state 2 expense, and to make available to the public, any and all public records, and 3 inventories, indices, or finding aids relating to those records that the institution 4 makes available to the public generally. Home address, home phone number, personal cellular phone number, birth 33 date, and personal email address of employee of public agency 34 7928.300. (a) The home addresses, home telephone numbers, personal cellular 35 telephone numbers, and birth dates of all employees of a public agency shall not be 36 deemed to be public records and shall not be open to public inspection, except that 37 disclosure of that information may be made as follows: 38 (1) To an agent, or a family member of the individual to whom the information 39 pertains. 40 (2) To an officer or employee of another public agency when necessary for the 41 performance of its official duties. 42 (3) To an employee organization pursuant to regulations and decisions of the 43 Public Employment Relations Board, except that the home addresses and any phone 44 numbers on file with the employer of employees performing law enforcement-45 related functions, and the birth date of any employee, shall not be disclosed. 46 Tentative Recommendation May 2019 - 141 - (4) To an agent or employee of a health benefit plan providing health services or 1 administering claims for health services to public agencies and their enrolled 2 dependents, for the purpose of providing the health services or administering claims 3 for employees and their enrolled dependents. 4 (b)(1) Unless used by the employee to conduct public business, or necessary to 5 identify a person in an otherwise disclosable communication, the personal email 6 addresses of all employees of a public agency shall not be deemed to be public 7 records and shall not be open to public inspection, except that disclosure of that 8 information may be made as specified in paragraphs (1) to (4), inclusive, of 9 subdivision (a). 10 (2) This subdivision shall not be construed to limit the public's right to access the 11 content of an employee's personal email that is used to conduct public business, as 12 decided by the California Supreme Court in City of San Jose v. Superior Court 13 (2017) 2 Cal.5th 608. 14 (c) Upon written request of any employee, a public agency shall not disclose the 15 employee's home address, home telephone number, personal cellular telephone 16 number, personal email address, or birth date pursuant to paragraph (3) of 17 subdivision (a) and an agency shall remove the employee's home address, home 18 telephone number, and personal cellular telephone number from any mailing list 19 maintained by the agency, except if the list is used exclusively by the agency to 20 contact the employee. 21 Comment. INTRODUCTORY PROVISIONS 22 § 7930.000. Legislative intent and instructions 23 7930.000. (a) It is the intent of the Legislature to assist members of the public and 24 state and local agencies in identifying exemptions to the California Public Records 25 Act. It is the intent of the Legislature that, after January 1, 1999, each addition or 26 amendment to a statute that exempts any information contained in a public record 27 from disclosure pursuant to Section 7927.705 shall be listed and described in 28 Chapter 2 (commencing with Section 7930.100) pursuant to a bill authorized by a 29 standing committee of the Legislature to be introduced during the first year of each 30 session of the Legislature. 31 (b) The statutes and constitutional provisions listed in Chapter 2 (commencing 32 with Section 7930.100) may operate to exempt certain records, or portions thereof, 33 from disclosure. The statutes and constitutional provisions listed and described may 34 not be inclusive of all exemptions. The listing of a statute or constitutional provision 35 in Chapter 2 (commencing with Section 7930.100) does not itself create an 36 exemption. Requesters of public records and public agencies are cautioned to review 37 the applicable statute or constitutional provision to determine the extent to which it, 38 in light of the circumstances surrounding the request, exempts public records from 39 disclosure. 40 Comment. This act would recodify the California Public Records Act (Sections 17 6250 to 6276.48, inclusive, of the Government Code) in a more user-friendly 18 manner without changing its substance, and make conforming revisions. Consistent 19 with subdivision (b) of Section 3 of Article I of the California Constitution, the 20 Legislature finds and declares: 21 (1) This act continues the existing substantive balance between the public's right 22 of access to information concerning the conduct of public business and competing 23 interests. This act does not impose any new limitation on the public's right of access, 24 which would require findings demonstrating the interest protected by the new 25 limitation and the need for protecting that interest. 26 (2) By making the California Public Records Act more user-friendly, this act 27 furthers the public's right of access to information concerning the conduct of public 28 business. 29 Operative date 30 SEC. ____.
